description:
Some people say: "Belgium is not colourful". Is this true?

Let's see.  We will have a approx. two hours theme photo walk through the lesser known parts of the City-Centre of Brussels with the theme “everything coloured red”.

Meeting point is at the monument Colonne du Congrès/Congreskolom, where we'll start our walk at 15:45.

There will be an amazing amount of interesting things (hopefully some red) to see plus some bars and cafes we can finish in.

Please RSVP!

Looking forward to see you all at the "Everything orange" - theme tour around Brussels city!
how_to_find_us: We meet at the monument Rue Royale / Tram - Bus Congrès / Metro Parc
name: Everything red - photo theme tour around Brussels city

description:
Happy Shuttercounts, we are close to the year's longest days and we can still see the sun at 10pm (if weather permits ;) giving us plenty of time for interesting shoots in the evening! Let's do something different after-work, let's meet and shoot. We will meet near Parc Royal (exact place will be announced later) and then walk towards the Marolles, through the Sablon, finishing in the city center. During this walk we will have a lot of opportunities to take the pictures of typical Brusselairs (local people and local objects).

We will not only have fun and an interesting time ;) we will also touch those subjects:

- Point-and-shoot vs. DSLR with fast lens or why sensor size matters (or not) we will experiment with depth of field (the 'blurred' background)
- Flashing the day away
How to create simulated night-scenes during daylight using a powerful flash
- Situations in which are small compact are the preferred tool

and of course we can discuss any other photography related questions

Yasemin
name: 3h to 3days before summer

description:
The Happy Shuttercounts will start this meet-up with another walk but afterwards we meet for a chat and a drink and of course photograph and related talks. First, we will do an exciting stroll through Brussels, giving lots of opportunities for great shots. Garden, green, street, architectures - you name it -, there will be something for all of us.

UPDATE

At the meet-up #3 we will see some hidden treasures, Parc Josaphat and one of the the most beautiful Avenues, the Avenue Louis Bertrand. If time allows we will also pass the last place where Henry Magritte used to live.

We will meet at the entrance of Parc Josaphat at the corner Avenue Louis Bertrand / Boulevard Lambermont (Tram Nr. 7 Stop Louis Bertrand, Bus 66 Crossing, walking 35 min from the center, by car - parking is easy)  Please be on time!

This will be the 3rd meet-up of the rapid growing group, all of us are 'new' to this group, many even just joined! As seen from the RSVP's, we will be a nicely homogeneous group, we will take the time we need to ask and explain but also to socialize and develop proposals for future Brussels Photography meet-up's.

IMPORTANT:

The weather forecast is promising, however, if it is going to rain heavily, a "Plan B" with more indoor-ish activity will be posted here (no change after 12:00 on Saturday)  - stay tuned!


The RSVP's "yes" will receive additional contact details. Please take the RSVP serious and update it if your plans change.


See all of you Happy Shuttercounts on Saturday!
Claus

venue.name: Parc Josaphat Brussels
venue.address_1: entrance at the corner Avenue Louis Bertrand / Boulevard Lambermont

name: Part 1 - Walk and talk and shoot

description:
THIS MEETUP IS ALMOST CANCELLED

UPDATE

The weather forecast for tomorrow (Saturday) - not very promising and really sad for the organiser of the music event.
If the weather is really awful, it wouldn't make much sense to go there except for taking pictures of the "Belgium summer festivals" ;( or listen to the music.

Anyhow, this meetup was already planned as 'show up as you want' in the first place, thus allowing the Happy Shuttercounts to arrive and go as they want.

However, when someone wants to go there Saturday or even Sunday - use the comments part or SMS to communicate.

I may be there for a while on Saturday and Sunday.

Claus

 

 

 

The summer in Brussels is packed with lots of events.

One of them is the

Brosella Folk and Jazz festival,

a free concert on Saturday and Sunday 14-15/6 at the open air (natural) theatre and stage in the woods a few hundred meter away from the Atomium and the final stop of Tram 7, 51 and Metro 6 (seen from the tram station, it's 'behind' the Atomium).

Surprisingly, it seems not to be well known, especially within the expat community, but it's definitely worth a visit - either for taking pictures or listening to the music - or both ;)


Check out the very good web-site. All information (including map) can be found at:
http://www.brosella.be/eng

This meet-up will not have an definite start- and end-time.

Happy Shuttercounts and friends may be there in as they arrive and leave. Communication will be through the pre-meetup conversation and TXT.
how_to_find_us: click on the map link or http://www.brosella.be/eng
name: Brussels Photography goes "Summer Concert"

description:
The Happy Shuttercounts go Bozar!
Details of this exciting exhibition are here: http://www.summerofphotography.be/en/exhibition/sense-place

We meet at 13:30 (please be on time ;) at the entrance of Bozar at Rue Royale (see map) - outside if the weather is fair or inside if it's raining.

If you have to change your plans, please change the RSVP or contact the organiser (you will receive additional contact details).

See you Sunday!
how_to_find_us: Bozar - Entrance Rue Royale
name: Visit exhibition: European Landscape Photography -  SENSE OF PLACE

description:
----- UPDATE ----
Happy Shuttercounts, mark the date for this very special event!

Trees and People's "fete dans les arbres"!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

It will be exiting, a bit adventurous, nature in the country side in a very beautiful region.

The Happy Shuttercounts are invited to this Barbecue, tree-climbing, exhibition event, one of the most beautiful areas of Belgium .... and:

The Happy Shuttercounts will have a photo challenge there with very special prices to win (really not an every-day-thing ;)!

The "fete dans les arbres" is organized by Trees&People SL. Details see picture. It's free - but they ask for a contribution to the barbecue (10 / 15 EUR).

Background:
Trees&People asked me last week, if I would come and take pictures at this event for their promotion and web-site. I said "No, not only me" but offered more than one camera - the whole Happy Shuttercounts meet-up camera team!

We can participate in the event as any other guest and even plug a tent to stay the night till Sunday (I know this place, it awesome).


But we are also invited to take nice, beautiful, interesting and funny pictures for the use by Trees&People, each participant delivering his or her five best pictures.


We won't do this for free - there is a very special price exclusively for one of the Happy Shuttercounts to win:

One night in a tent installed on a platform high in the trees for two persons!


(we need some discussions how we will choose: either the best/funniest etc. picture or a a lottery type selection...? - the organizer (Claus) will not participate.)

How to get there:
By Car:
Most will depart from Brussels, Montgomery Area at around 12:00 on Saturday, going in a small convoy. Is is about one hour drive. We may organize some car-sharing.
Click here and on the map close to the title, the position of the pointer is accurate (Lat:[masked], Lon:[masked])

By Train:
the closest Train station to Venalte is Yvoir . The Trains are running Saturday / Sunday on an hourly basis, time to Brussels Midi is approx. 1:30 hours. Timetable at http://www.sncb.be. Be sure you have the contact phone number (those of Claus, by separate mail or another Happy Shuttercount) so we can pick you up at Yvoir.

Camping:
If you want, you even can stay overnight for taking sunset / sunrise / landscape / wildlife pictures (but see warning below).
There is plenty space to plug a tent. However, this place is a private garden and not an official camp-site.

Hunting warning!
I was informed, that it is not recommended to go hiking deep into the woods nearby! Hunting season has started and there will be some hunting ongoing this weekend in this private forest. However, staying around the Trees&People Experiential' Site is safe.

More updates may follow, stay tuned!


Use the discussion or private contact for questions. Please take the RSVP serious.


Detailed info will follow how we will arrange the payment for the barbecue (recommended) and the RSVP to Trees & People.

venue.name: 'Trees&People Experiential' Site in Venalte, Belgium (near Crupet, Namur)

name: Trees-Nature-Climbing-Animation-Barbecue-Photo competition

description:
Let's go to the fair!

We can enjoy it and also shoot pictures in this very special ambience (lights, people..)

Let's meet next to the big wheel at 16h! We'll wait +-15min for those who could arrive later

If you aren't on time and if we have left the meeting point, you'll be able to recognize us with our cameras ;)


Info:

Blvd du Midi, 1000 Brussels, between the Porte de Halle and the Porte d'Anderlecht


Ever since then, the Midi Fair, the most important fair in Brussels, has opened each year on the weekend before Belgium’s national holiday on the 21st of July. The Midi Fair is held throughout July and August, for over one month and is situated between Porte d’Anderlecht/Anderlechtsepoort and Porte de Hal/Hallepoort.

Over the years, the once classical fair has greatly evolved and applied the newest technological developments to its fairground attractions. Traditional images like wrestling rings, fortune tellers, merry-go-rounds, and street organs have made way for modern variants such as bumper cars, roller coasters, and big wheels.

http://www.foiredumidi.be/UK/
name: Foire du midi / Zuidfoor

description:
Happy Shuttercounts, before the trees go orange and even brown or maybe white, why not take a walk in the forest along with our cameras?

Taking pictures of trees (foret de Soignes): Just trees? only trees? this could be a beautiful challenge: colour (sharpeness), b&w, different focus, aperture, movement.

And a challenge made easier if we also go to the beautiful Rouge Cloitre and its beautiful lakes and artist exhibits (and I think they have a nice cafe).

Let's meet at 5pm on the parking slot of 'Dreve des Brules', which stands on the Avenue de Tervuren (coming from Montgomery going towards Tervuren/the Ring). You can also go there with the tram 44, leaving Montgomery (11 stops, 14 min ride). Please see below the link of the meeting place.

On saturday, I'll send a private message to the people who have registered, with my mobile number, in case you need help finding the meeting place.

Please be on time, as once we will have left the parking slot, it will be difficult to find each other in the forest ;)

Looking forward to see a lot of Happy Shuttercounts!

(points B/C) ttps://maps.google.com/maps?q=Dreve+Des+Brules,+1150+St-Pieters-Woluwe,+Bruxelles,+Belgique&hl=fr&ll=50.818896,4.457209&spn=0.009557,0.022724&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=48.688845,93.076172&oq=dre&geocode=FafOBwMdf0VDAClf-XQoVdvDRzFMNdS4rsQdgg%3BFW2ABwMdowZEACk_V-l_n9vDRzE1rEChsOe7dA&hnear=Dreve+Des+Brules&t=m&z=16&start=0
name: Hiking (walking) and taking pictures

description:
We will meet close to the Palais de Justice but NOT visit it this time (you can do it nearly every working day or if you so wish before the meet-up)

This is the car-free Sunday!

We can shoot from positions which are usually crowded by traffic (still be aware of bicycles ;)
But during this weekend there is another unique opportunity:

Once a year, there are the Heritage Days in Brussels (Journées du patrimoine or Open Monumentendagen), Saturday 15 and Sunday 16 September 2012.
It is the event to discover the wealth of buildings, institutions and Brussels real-estate. The public will have access to areas which are normally not accessible. Brussels and Communes are packed with interesting buildings and places.
We will pick some, mainly in the Center of Brussels but we also may dis-locate (probably even by Bus  not to loose too much time while changing locations).

Clearly, the goal is to see places which are normally not accessible.

And - of course the intention is to share knowledge. This meet-up will give photographic opportunities to everybody, and experts can help and advice the less experienced.

It's as usual: always someone knows something which the others don't know ;)


Use the forum for discussions!

You will find details on the Heritage Days here:
http://www.brussels.be/artdet.cfm?id=7562


Stay tuned, the exact meeting location will be published soon.
Claus
how_to_find_us: We meet in the middle of Place Poelaert Plein at the monument, nearly in front of the Palais de Justice (if its raining {no,no} at the entrace of the Palais de Justice). Tram stop Poelaert and Tram/Metro Louise are close.
name: A city without  (car) traffic -> Car Free Sunday 2012 and Heritage Days

description:
Meet-up open to those who participated at Trees-Nature-Climbing-Animation-Barbecue-Photo competition and guests.


We have a Winner! Lots of super pictures but finally one was chosen!!!
Bruno said, it was not an easy task - even from the four finalists.
But now : This is the winning Picture!!!

 

 

And - of course: This needs to be celebrated!

We will have a BBQ. Mark the date: 22/23 September!
Feel free to bring a friend!

Care will be taken of the winner but all the others: Bring some drinks and food and a sleeping bag (to stay overnight).

description:
Update
As announced earlier, the former “Urban gardening and guerilla gardens” meet-up had to change. We can't and don't want create threats to those sometimes tiny spots - it's not feasible to do this with a large meetup-group.

Beautiful and mystical
What is now proposed is even better! It's a place close to Brussels, easily accessible for everybody.
If the weather is nice, it's beautiful, if not, it can be even mystical. Especially when autumn spreads it's decent colors everywhere. Surprisingly it's not very well known among the expat scene. It is the National Botanic Garden of Belgium in Meise (a bit - ca. 3km - north of the Atomium).
Outside, there are so many different types of trees which you will rarely see arranged like this anywhere in the world! Not enough, the large greenhouse with its amazing variety of plants is also worth a visit.
<a>http://www.br.fgov.be/index.php
</a>

last year in October

What to bring
So, bring of course your camera, if you have, your macro and zoom equipment and whatever you may need for landscape AND close-ups. Of course, we will as usual discuss, ask and explain as we go. Don't worry, if you don't have a special photo gear. I have seen stunning pictures which were taken with an instamatic.

What we will do
Also this time, we will be a good mix of experts and beginners sharing the same passion and don't forget: there is always someone who knows something which all the others don't know. We also will have a small challenge for the excitement ;)

What if
As usual, we can expect the weather condition will be perfect for that day, we will meet in any case and in case its raining heavily, there is also the greenhouse and there are some shelters in the park.

Autmnpicknick
Bring some cheese/sausage/etc and something to drink. We will try to have a pick-nick, propably in on of those tiny weather shelters.   

How to get  there
<a>http://www.br.fgov.be/PUBLIC/GENERAL/howtoreach.php
</a> Adress: Jardin botanique national de Belgique
Nieuwelaan 38
1860 Meise
By Car. We also can do some car-sharing. Start the discussion.
By Bus to Meise. Stop is "Nationale Plantentuin".
You can use the planner: http://www.delijn.be/en/index.htm with the street address above. In practical terms, we may form two groups. One is coming by bus from Brussels, the others go directly.

Questions
If you have any questions, please contact the organizer or start a discussion.

Links
General http://www.br.fgov.be/PUBLIC/GENERAL/index.php
how_to_find_us: At the main entrance

description:
With the start of the rainy-season in Belgium we will start our 'light' talks about photography but also continue to provide a forum to meet people sharing the same passion - photography.

Practical - tutorials - learn and share.
This is the first of a series meet-up's each organised in three phases: start with a casual get together followed by an introduction to the main subject, followed by practical exercises or background information. Finally, there will be an open conversation where we will have detailed talks about the subject or general questions related to photography.

No. 1 will address basic functionality of the camera, exposure (aperture, ISO and shutter speed), depth of field and sensor size as well as white balance.

Bring your camera, some snacks and drink.
name: It's [not] all about light - No.1: Camera Basics

Looking forward seeing you,

description:
#### update as of 06 dec 2012 ######
Weather forecast Monschau / Saturday
Sunny, 5,2 hours sunshine, -4 C, rain probability 5% (no rain), wind 11-24 km/h  N)
DONT FORGET YOUR GLOVES AND SUNGLASSES

#### update as of 04 dec 2012 ######

WHAT

Everybody seems to be already hyper busy those days before Christmas. Calm down this Saturday, grep your camera gear and enjoy the first Happy-Shuttercount-Snow-Expedition with train-  and bus-ride to the Christmas marked in the small German town of Monschau.

It is going to snow over there the whole week with temperatures just below zero.

See the web-cam images of Monschau (upper left is the recent one): http://www.monschau.de/service/webcam_historie.php

 

With the fresh snow it will be really beautiful, Glühwein and Aachener Printen will help against the cold and there will be many great opportunities to take wonderful pictures, in Monschau http://www.germany-christmas-market.org.uk/monschau_christmas_market.php and on the way.

HOW TO GET THERE

Public transport:

Monschau is about 160 km east of Brussels. I was surprised how easy it is to get there with public transport.

Trains run from Brussels to Eupen, a small Village in east Belgium. From there, it takes 29 minutes with the bus to Monschau.

The Train costs € 9,90 return (!) with the SNCB Christmas deal promo; the bus may cost the same.

At 12:02, Gare Central take the IC 510 Direction Eupen [B] to Eupen Station, arriving at 13:45. Talk to the other Happy Shuttercounts during the trip and have your camera gear ready for on-the-way photos.

At 14:01 catch the bus 385 at Eupen Station direction "Kalter Herberg". Get off at "Monschau Parkhaus" at 14:25. THIS IS THE MEETING TIME/POINT.

RETURN

At 17:30 take bus 385 at "Monschau Parkhaus" direction Eupen.

17:54 get off at Eupen Bahnhof (Station).

At 18:15 take the IC 541 direction Ostende and dont forget to get off in Brussels at around 19:58

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

By car:

consult google maps or your GPS. The parking in Monschau is difficult. There is the 'Parkhaus' and there may also be a shuttle service - ask me if you need more details

Meeting point is "Monschau Parkhaus" / Schmiede (see map above) at 14:25 when the Bus arrives.

###### end of update 4/12 #######

 

Street, decoration, people pre-celebrating, low light and what else to spot on a Christmas market?

But -- we will not necessarily go to a Marked in Brussels. The 'where' will depend on some factors: Weather (snow?), road conditions, transport availability, ... So, it may be Brussels but also a marked in the romantic Belgium or German villages like Monschau or Eupen (with snow?) ... stay tuned for updates...
name: Christmas is coming - Expedition in the snow - Christmas marked and more!

following many suggestions, this is a last-last-minute meetup call.

description:
History and Carnival: Photoresk - the Brussels Photography going Tournay

Tournay, the 2nd oldest Town of Belgium (after Tongeren). The picturesque medieval city center. The beautiful market place, the the river Escaut ("Schelde" in Dutch), some UNESCO world heritage sites and -

Carnival? Yes, Carnival!

When nearly everywhere in the rest of the world the carnival season is over, the inner part of Tournai is closed for traffic to celebrate carnival. Probably a good idea to wait 'till spring and definitely something not to miss while in Belgium. Details about the carnival in Tournai can be found here (in french) http://www.carnavaldetournai.be/

What

There will be an parade starting at 14:30 at four different places heading towards the centre. This will be a fantastic opportunity to take great picture of Belgium habits ;) and the city.

How

We will take the train from Brussels central at 13:16 and return to Brussels at around 20:00. Meeting point is in front of Starbucks inside Gare Central.

Trains are leaving Brussels Gare Central hourly at x:16.

Return is also hourly at x:41 the last train from Tournai to Brussels is at 22:41.

The ride takes in either direction 1:03 hours, the SNCB return ticket (week-end) is around 14€
how_to_find_us: In front of Starbucks
name: Only one hour from Brussels: Tournay: History, Carnival and Belgium Traditions

description:
Here are the details:

Where

We will go to Gent - Ghent - Gand (it's all the same ;) - our walk will start at

14:00. Meeting point is the Korenmarkt /  St Niklaas Church in the centre of Ghent.

Here is a map of the location http://goo.gl/maps/U5T61

We will have a nice walk through the beautiful city with the lovely places and lots to see. And - we will try also try some of the local specialities.

There will be many, many opportunities for great shots. Of course, as we go along, there will be time to ask questions and share knowledge!

</a>How to get there

The easiest way from Brussels is by Train. The return ticket (weekend ticket) is around 9€ but for those who go by car - probably you can give someone a lift. Use the message board.

For those coming from Brussels by train, there are two trains per hour to Ghent. We will meet at 12:00 in front of Starbucks at Brussels Central.
We will take the train IC1533 Direction Knokke at 12:21, Platform 2. Arrival in Ghent will be at 12:57. From the Station to Korenmarkt is a 2km walk (just follow the rails of tram 1) or a ride with Tram 1 until stop Korenmarkt (at the Station, there is only Tram 4 and Final of Tram 1 - quite easy)

The route is here <a href="http://goo.gl/maps/Wheee">http://goo.gl/maps/Wheee

Some nice information about Ghent is on this use-it map:

http://www.use-it.travel/cities/detail/ghent/

Sometimes there are long lines at the ticket counters at Gare Central, consider to get your (weekend) ticket from the web-site.

As Daniel mentioned, there is Saint Patricks's day on Sunday! We will see a lot of green!

See you all in Ghent!

UPDATE:

I've updated the map. The pointer now shows the exact position of the entrance. We will meet just behind the entrance to the Royal Park (but before the cashier).

For those using public transport, here are some proposals (but there are other options, e.g fom Hysel / Atomium and having a nice walk) Route proposal by Google

It will be sunny and dry tomorrow (yes!); there are no places (restaurants) to go in the direct vicinity of the the greenhouses - but the nice park of Laeken outside the Royal Place. Probably we will just find us a nice spot to do some aftermaths/feedback.

By tonight I will send all who RSVP 'yes' my GSM number - just in case.

Please be on time - we'll enter at 11:00

____________________________________________________

Every spring, the Royal Greenhouses of Laeken are open to the public for 3 weeks.This is the only time when the Royal Greenhouses are accessible to the public.

It is an excellent opportunity to see the wonderful architecture of Alphonse Balat, the mentor of Victor Horta, and the many plants in the greenhouses.

Take your camera and shoot ...... wonderful architecture and plants!!!

We will start over with improving the basic skills of photography and have some nice opportunities for macro shots!

After visiting the greenhouse (is 2,5 hours realistic?) we will get together somewhere either in a brasserie or go over to the park or Japanese tower but this will depend on the weather forecast. 
(update and info how to get there will follow in due course)

PS: it may be crowded later - that's why at 11:00 - it's early for a Saturday but worthwhile ;)

Here is the Wikipedia article: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Greenhouses_of_Laeken

Walk and talk and shoot

But first, we will do an exciting stroll through Brussels, with lots of opportunities for great shots - there will be something for all of us.

description:
also see update below in the discussion

The new way to overcome limitations we noticed when we did the last portrait session. One 'model' and more than 10 photographers at the same time will not work well. Speed-Shooting® is the answer. With Speed-Shooting® we can have up to 20 individuals improving their portrait taking skills.

Simple, effective and a lot of fun: outdoor speed-shooting

What:

We will do an intensive portrait shooting. After this Meetup you will be the portrait specialist at friends- and family-events ;) and you also will know how to direct light-assistants and 'models' ;)


How:

After some general basics and discussions about portrait styles we will form groups of three. The photographer, the portrait-model and the light-assistant. Each group will have some basic light forming equipment available.
Each photographer has 15 minutes time to work with the model, shooting portraits but also instructing model and light-assistant.

After the 15 minutes and a five minutes break the roles will change. Photographer will become model, the model light-assistant.

After three rounds each of us Happy Shuttercounts will have been photographer, model and light-assistant.

Where:

Brussels / outdoor - but we may adopt the location depending on the  freshness of the summer ;)

Do's and Don'ts for the Speed-Shooting (TM) Meetup
General:
The Photographer:
Take wonderful pictures and give electronic copies to the model. Respect the personality rights. You must ask the model for permission if you want to publish pictures.   
The Model:
You may use the pictures on which you are depicted at your discretion but ask the photographer wether or not the photographers name shall be mentioned.

In more detail:
By participation you agree to the following principles:  
The goal of the Speed-Shooting Meetup is to improve the photography related skills. During the Speed-Shooting Meetup each participant will take the role of a model (M), photographer (P) or light-assistant (L), respectively. The following rules refers to the role(s) taken by the individual during the meetup-event. The participant acknowledges that  pictures taken during the meetup shall be royalty-free and will be made available in electronic form to a) the person depicted (M,L) and b) to a password protected area of a photo sharing site to which only participants of the Speed-Shooting Meetup-event concerned have access. Any publication of a portrait photograph requires consent between P and the person depicted.
how_to_find_us: We meet in Cinquantenaire close to the entrance of Autoworld.
name: Practising portrait: speed-shooting®

description:
This is the first Belgian retrospective of the work of the English photographer Martin Parr.

http://www.galerieparisbeijing.com/exhibitions/pr_pages/parr_brussels_2013.html

Parr's approach to documentary photography is intimate, anthropological and satirical. Macro lenses, ring flash, high-saturation colour film, and since it became an easier format to work in, digital photography, all allow him to put his subjects "under the microscope" in their own environment, giving them space to expose their lives and values in ways that often involve inadvertent humour.[wikipedia]
name: Visit exposition: Martin Parr Retrospektive

description:

See all of you Happy Shuttercounts on Sunday!
Claus, your organiser

description:
Update

We will be a large group this time, photo enthusiasts with a wide range of experience and skill levels. We also will be happy to welcome plenty Happy Shuttercounts which are new to our meetup group.

The weather will be fair, our walk will last around two to three hours with plenty of opportunities for interesting pictures. And - don't forget, it's also about learning and sharing. Be curious and ask - if asked, share your knowledge and explain. After the walk we  may get together for an review and drink.

The theme for our walk

Signs and Symbols

Our theme for this walk are signs and symbols. You will find them everywhere, not necessarily only as traffic signs. Watch out for them. Take great pictures. Be creative.

Signs and Symbols are not your thing? Feel free to find your own which is matching your visual interest or just get inspired from what is happening around you.

Weather

I will be overcast and dry tomorrow with temperatures up to 20C (!) -> no hard shadows!

What else?

Put your camera manual in your bag just in case you have questions to the settings ;-)

The rough plan

http://photos2.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/4/b/f/c/600_285319452.jpegWe will meet at "A" and have our walk in the aereas marked in red (depending on  where the interesting things are happening) 

General information about the Car Free Sunday:

The public transport like busses and tram will operate. The STIB and De Lijn will be free of charge on that day.

The Car Free Sunday will be valid for everybody, except taxis, journey buses, assistance services, police and persons with a special permit. Vehicles authorized to circulate in Brussels during this day will have to respect the maximal speed of 30 kilometres per hour. The whole Brussels Region will be closed for traffic from 9:00 till 19:00.
name: A city without  (car) traffic -> Car Free Sunday 2013

description:
Update:
Already more than 50 Happy Shutterconts singed up. We are going to beat or record!

This time, we will have something new: Upon arrival at the meetup location, ask your organiser for the secret code. You will need it later.

Our walk will be a little bit shorter than previously announced (around 4 km).

We will roughly take the same route as described by Oliver here: http://www.gpsmycity.com/tours/art-nouveau-on-the-go-1015.html (the app seems to be broken on the iPhone?) to see some very interesting parts of town, have great opportunities to take nice pictures.

And - again, the very balanced mix of creativities and skill levels! Be ready to ask questions and provide answers and have a great afternoon out.

After the walk, we may go for a snack and/or drink to share some final thoughts.

Weather:

after some rain and thunderstorms on Friday and probably Saturday, Sunday will be overcast with sunny spells. No hard shadows ;-)

----------------------------------- end of update -------

 

Our Plan

We will have an approx 6 km walk during which we will see some of the most famous Art Nouveau buildings in Brussels and - as usual - have to great opportunity for photography related chats.

Hint: it's not a bad idea to carry the manual of your camera if you are going to ask some specific questions

Is this meetup for you?

This meetup will be as nice, entertaining and educating as all out other meetup so far but to avoid any disappointments you should notice that we will not be able to visit any of the buildings from inside as part of this meetup.


If you want to see more

if you want to see the building from inside, you have to get tickets ( one weekend 20€ / four weekends 55€) from the organisation which is responsible for  Biennale Art Nouveau Event in Brussels and pre-register for the visits (Photoresk has no affiliation with them) and create your own itinerary.

Finally: a little warning COPYRIGHT

the copyright rules are quite different in different (even EU) countries. Belgium has become famous for the restrictive application of architects rights. I am not going to judge here if individuals who are shaping our living environment have the right to protect elements which are in public sight as their property but I suggest everybody to have a look at the Atomium web-site since the same applies to many buildings in Belgium.
Reccomended reading: http://atomium.be/authorsrights.aspx?lang=en

However, this should not stop you from taking pictures - but you should be aware and consider what you will do with the photos later on
how_to_find_us: we will meet directly at the medivial tower at Porte de Hal

description:
Update: (schedule and where to meet)

There are two options to get there. By train and bus or car. Last year most of us took the train/bus which was easy and very relaxing. 

Others came by car and we met there. 

The timetable would be as such that it's either the train at 12:00 from Central or - for those who take the car or share a car 14:30 in Monschau. The only issue is parking in Monschau  - very limited and nearly impossible so everybody will be forced to park outside and take a shuttle.

By train is probably the best option. For those taking the train, we will meet at Central in front of the Starbucks 

.....................

Street, decoration, people pre-celebrating, low light and what else to spot on a Christmas market?

(Photo by george.simeon - during 2012 Photoresk visit to Monschau)


We did it last year and we will do it again: The Christmas Marked in the small medieval German town Monschau

Everybody seems to be already hyper-busy those days before Christmas. Calm down this Saturday, grep your camera gear and enjoy the  Happy-Shuttercount--Expedition with train-  and bus-ride to the Christmas marked in the small German town of Monschau.

It is going to snow over there next week with temperatures just below zero.

See the web-cam images of Monschau (upper left is the recent one): http://www.monschau.de/service/webcam_historie.php

With the fresh snow it will be really beautiful, Glühwein and Aachener Printen will help against the cold and there will be many great opportunities to take wonderful pictures, in Monschau http://www.germany-christmas-market.org.uk/monschau_christmas_market.php and on the way.

HOW TO GET THERE

Public transport:

Monschau is about 160 km east of Brussels. I was surprised how easy it is to get there with public transport.

Trains run from Brussels to Eupen, a small Village in east Belgium. From there, it takes 29 minutes with the bus to Monschau.

The Train costs € 10 return (!) with the SNCB Christmas deal promo; the bus may cost the same.

At 12:02, Gare Central take the IC 510 Direction Eupen [B] to Eupen Station, arriving at 13:45. Talk to the other Happy Shuttercounts during the trip and have your camera gear ready for on-the-way photos.

At 14:01 catch the bus 385 at Eupen Station direction "Kalter Herberg". Get off at "Monschau Parkhaus" at 14:25. THIS IS THE MEETING TIME/POINT.

RETURN

At 17:30 take bus 385 at "Monschau Parkhaus" direction Eupen.

17:54 get off at Eupen Bahnhof (Station).

At 18:15 take the IC 541 direction Ostende and don't forget to get off in Brussels at around 19:58

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

By car:

consult google maps or your GPS. The parking in Monschau is difficult. There is the 'Parkhaus' and there may also be a shuttle service - ask me if you need more details

Meeting point is "Monschau Parkhaus" / Schmiede (see map above) at 14:25 when the Bus arrives.

description:
A small group of photographers interested in Streetlife, go out on the streets together, share tips, take shots, after a few hours find a welcoming cafe and go through every bodies selections, preferably with a laptop…
Limit 8 members to keep it reasonable.

More details;

RDV @ 1.30pm, Full itinerary given and discussed.

2.00pm we will split into smaller groups and explore specific zones, hopefully in good daylight I can't promise sun unfortunately but we will work with whatever is given to us, if it rains heavily I have some indoor location ideas.

4.00pm regroup; Q&A; Troubleshooting. Form new groups and explore different zones in low light and dusk… perhaps we might have some blue light.

6pm regroup; find a cafe; upload pictures; select; critique; present to the group for evaluation and feedback.

8pm estimated end.

All times are approximate and can very depending on various aspects.

What you will need;

1 camera DSLR or good compact with enough disk space, + extra disk, 16GB should be enough for 4 hours.

2 fully charged camera batteries, keep spare battery warm; cold batteries quickly loose their charge.

I would recommend the full frame equivalent of a 35mm or 50mm fixed lens for street photography, but if all you have is a small zoom it will also be good, you really want something small, light and responsive, any doubts please contact me.

1 Laptop with battery fully charged with Lightroom or similar soft installed and enough free space.

If you don't have a laptop you can still take part but I think you will miss the most valuable part of this meetup, to select, show and discuss your results with the group and above all learning from the mistakes because often we learn more from our mistakes then our successes, sharing these can be very rewarding.

+ Rugsack or comfortable shoulder bag and warm clothing.

What you don't need: Tripod/ multiple lens/ etc.

More details later...
name: Street Photography in Brussels

description:

Véronique exhibits her photography together with the work of three other artists.
An guided tour by Christina Ruggin, the curator of the photo and art exhibition in Charleroi is organised. The expo is at Intérieur privé - rue de l'Eglise 2, 6032 Mont-sur-Marchienne, Belgique http://www.interieurprive.com/?p=atelier

Option: The Musée de la Photographie à Charleroi http://www.museephoto.be/‎ is nearby, we may combine the visits (or get at least an 'preview' for an later visit).

To get there:
 A) We will arrange some car-sharing

B) take a train from gares du nord, centrale et midi; it takes approx. 50 minutes to Charleroi gare du sud.
There are direct buses (70, 71 et 170) and only three stops.
name: Art and Photograpy

description:
Everybody knows the Grand place, the EU Quarter, the Sablon etc.. I propose we discover by foot some of the less well known areas of Brussels. Format will be more or less the same as previous event "Street photography in Brussels"

What you will need;

1 camera DSLR or good compact with enough disk space, + extra disk, 16GB should be enough for 4 hours.

2 fully charged camera batteries, keep spare battery warm; cold batteries quickly loose their charge.

I would recommend the full frame equivalent of a 35mm or 50mm fixed lens for street photography, but if all you have is a small zoom it will also be good, you really want something small, light and responsive, any doubts please contact me.

1 Laptop or iPad with battery fully charged with Lightroom or similar soft installed and enough free space.

If you don't have a laptop you can still take part but I think you will miss the most valuable part of this meetup, to select, show and discuss your results with the group and above all learning from the mistakes because often we learn more from our mistakes then our successes, sharing these can be very rewarding.

+ Rugsack or comfortable shoulder bag and warm clothing.

What you don't need: Tripod/ multiple lens/ etc.

More details later… I won't limit the numbers this time but if we are too big a group we might have to split.
name: Walk on the Wildside - Street photography in Brussels less frequented quarters

UPDATE[masked]

Hi all,

To follow up with some more details on this event, I have put together a proposed timeframe for people who may wish to take the train. Please be advised that it requires one change at Denderleeuw.

OUTBOUND:

From:Bru.-Centraal  To:Geraardsbergen [NMBS/SNCB] 13:16 dep - 14:22 arr

RETURN:

From:Geraardsbergen [NMBS/SNCB] To:Bru.-Centraal 20:34 dep - 21:57 arr

or

From:Geraardsbergen [NMBS/SNCB]To:Bru.-Centraal 21:38 dep - 22:44 arr

With this in mind, we should arrive at 14:22, giving us about 30 minutes to get in position for the start of the parade. I think one of the key photographic opportunities will be the "Tonnekensbrand" at 20:00, as it should be an exciting spectacle. 

I included the 20:34 train as an option for people who may want to leave earlier, as it is quite a long day, though you may miss some of the "Tonnekensbrand" activities.

For all those taking the 13:16 train from Brussels Central, I propose that you meet outside Starbucks at 13:00, as a way to gather all the group. I also propose that you purchase your train tickets in advance online. I am still undecided as to whether I will take the train or drive, but I will either meet you at Starbucks or in Geraardsbergen.

• If you are taking the train, please put your name down on this Doodle: http://www.doodle.com/wmesfbw6sfd96xwb 

If anyone knows for sure that they will drive and are happy for members to join them in their car, please post a comment in the group, to let everyone know. Normally, we meet at White Night on Montgomery roundabout when sharing transport.

Looking forward to the event, hopefully it stays dry and we get some great shots as well as meet new people :) .

A bientot,

Jon

UPDATE[masked]

Hi all, I received some more info from the tourism agency this morning:
The historic parade starts at 15:00 h, in the centre of the city at 'Hunnegem'. Of course, because of the big success every year, I advise you to come a bit earlier.
From Hunnegem, the parade goes throughout the streets of the centre of the city, up to the highest top of the 'Oudenberg'.There, near the chapel of the Oudenberg, the parade ends with the throwing of the 'Krakelingen'.
At 20:00 h  the "Tonnekensbrand" is burned on top of the Oudenberg while folk dance sets the atmosphere.
It is possible to travel by train from Brussels to Geraardsbergen. On Sunday, your trip to Geraardsbergen will go via Denderleeuw, where you will have to change to another train. You can find the exact hours in the station of Brussels."
So it looks like public transport may be an option, the following looks like a suitable schedule, allowing us enough time in the afternoon to try get good positions and enough time in the evening  to watch the "Tonnekensbrand" and get back to the train station.
Out:12:27 dep13:27 arr
In:21:34 dep22:33 arr
Of course driving is also a possibility, though since it's a festival atmosphere and quite a long day, people may want to have a drink, in which case public transport would make sense. 

Initial message:

Hi all, I mentioned to Claus about an event I saw recently and he proposed I suggest it to the group. I saw photos of it online a while back and thought it looked interesting, it's called Krakelingen & Tonnekensbrand and is held on Sunday February 23rd in the city of Grammont/Geraardsbergen, about 1 hour drive west of Brussels. http://www.geraardsbergen.be/content/content/record.php?ID=2195

There could be potential for some good shooting opportunities, lots of costumes, day & night activities, fire and druids! If you do a Google Image search for "Krakelingen & Tonnekensbrand", you can get an idea of what to expect.

Cheers, 
Jon

description:
time in the evening with this magic light...
Blue hour is slightly misleading,  usually it last around half an hour hour after sunset. We will try to capture some nice city views. Later we will do some low-light / night shots.

----- UPDATE ----------

Looking forward to see you tomorrow for the Blue Hour Photoresk Meetup.

Weather and timing
The weather-forecast is very promising, mainly sunny at 15C. Sunset will be 19:08, expect nice light - the 'blue hour' until 20:00.

Later it will become so dark that higher ISO or even longer exposure times are necessary. Remember: higher ISO means more noise, longer exposure times increase the risk of motion blur and require a tripod or something else to keep the camera in a steady position.


No clue, what I am talking about, ISO, shutter speed? Don't worry, stay curious and ask tomorrow ;-)


Prepare
In preparation for tomorrow, you may want to consult your camera manual and have an idea how to switch the flash off and to put your camera in manual or shutter priority mode, set the ISO and the metering  to spot or center-weighted average. Put the manual in your bag.
Advanced, who want to experiment may check how to change between first and second curtain flash trigger....

If you have a tripod, bring it. If you don't have one, just don't go and buy a cheap one - choosing the right tripod will affect all your future work with it and there are some important things to consider. We will deal with those technical aspects at another meetup if there is some interest.
If you don't have a tripod, try to bring something on which you can put the camera in a stable way and keep motions away from it. This can be the famous granny's cherry stone cushion or a freezer bag half filled with salt or grain - you just have to find a suitable wall or other support underneath :-)

Location
The location will allow for both, city-views and later the combination of fading ambient light from traffic e.g. on Rue Royale towards Palais de Justice.

Safety
When taking pictures in traffic, always remember that Brussels drivers are now very famous for careful driving - stay safe :-)

Suggestions and inputs are -as usual- welcome - share your experience, we are all curious ;-)
------end update ----------------

Hopefully we have clear sky ....

Capturing light of the blue hour will require a longer exposure time than normal daytime photos.If you have a tripos - bring it. Or borrow granny's cherry stone cushion to put the camera steady on a wall.

What else?

You may want to check how to set your camera to spot<a href="http://photography.about.com/od/takingpictures/ss/darkphotos_3.htm"></a> or center-weighted average metering. It's a good idea to put your camera manual in your bag just in case you have questions to the settings ;-)

Yes, it's very early for a Saturday morning. Very early.

But it's only once a year. In April. In Belgium. Close to Halle. Bluebells covering the forest floor like a carped. In one week or so, it will be over....

Close to sunrise is the best time of the day for stunning pictures.


Hallerbos is about 35 minutes drive-time away from the centre of Brussels. The best way to get there is by car. You can find details about hallerbos here.

Sunrise in Halle on April, 12th is at 6:56. We will meet at the parking of Het Kriekske at 06:45. You will not miss the 'Photoresk Berlin' expedition truck. From the parking, we will driver further into the woods to a more central location.

description:
Photo-day in Liège!

For our hungry cameras, I propose 2 of Belgium’s most remarkable spots: Liège’s Calatrava train station and the stair/street called “Montagne de Bueren”. At the same time, we will visit one of the exhibitions of the 9th Biennial of Photography of Liège.

Calatrava’s station is the magnificent (and costly) work of architect Santiago Calatrava.
This building is a pleasure for the eyes, but it’s a trick for your camera! Bring your zoom or the widest-angle lens you have. This beast is not so easy to capture! I’m very curious what we will get.

The second imposed theme is the street “Montagne de Bueren”. The street is actually a 374-steps stairs. How you will put this into your frame is the name of the game ;-) Here, I would rather suggest a tele-lens. See Google Images for inspiration.

Between both shooting sessions, we will have a look at a photo-exhibition: “Idole” in the Cité Miroir. It looks like a very interesting exhibition about the power of images (More info on: http://bip-liege.org/en/exhibitions/cite-miroir/ ). 

Tentative timing:
- 9:45: Meeting at Brussels Central station, at the locket. Please purchase your own ticket to Liège (Weekend return tickets costs +/- 15,80 eur).
- 10:02: Train leaves 

- 11:00: Arrival at Liège’s Calatrava station – on the spot! We stay there +/- one hour to take pictures. 

- 12:00: Walk or bus to the city centre. Visit of the photo exhibition “Idole” in the Cité Miroir.
- 13:00: Lunch. I’ll try to book an affordable and popular restaurant. Off course everyone is free to grab some sandwich and stroll in the city.
- 14:00: Walk and shoot around the Montagne de Bueren, the second spot. Discovery of the this hilly and very old neighborhood. 

- 15:30: Let’s drink a Jupiler and talk about our experience. Those in a hurry can catch the 16:00 train. Then we walk back to the station
- 17:00: Train leaves to Brussels. For those who miss the train, there are other trains to Brussels every hour.
name: Liège: Photo Biennial + 2 imposed themes

description:
For more than a decade, Doel (a subdivision of Beveren), is threatened with complete demolition due to the future enlargement of the harbour of Antwerp. The town has been mostly depopulated, leaving a canvas for street artists. A bit more information over the town can be found on the following page: http://www.doel2020.org/page.php?ID=134 

There is a "touristic season" open from April until September. Visiting Doel by car is the easiest way. Public transportation doesn’t service Doel very often. (For those brave enough to try, there is one bus, nr. 83 that can be taken at the end of the pre-metro line of tram nr. 3 from Antwerp Central, but not all busses go as far as Doel. More information on public transport options are available on http://www.doel2020.org/Documentatie/Openbaar%20vervoer.htm)
name: Doel, the ghost town of Belgium

description:
Important for the submission: I've just learned that the final print must be A3 landscape!!! No portrait format. Sorry, I was not aware of this.

Update 7 July:
 We will make some experiments, maybe just some background "Church" shoots towards the blue hour. Sunset is close to 22:00, we will meet at 21:00 between the two metro exits. Bring  - if you have - your tripod and some small x-mas deco stuff.

Update 6 July:

First of all a very big "thank you" to all who submitted inputs!
 By now we have received some nice photos, however, to be honest, I had expected much more inputs to have an even broader choice for the selection of the best suited photos or images. So far only 13 candidate photo's are received as inputs, this number would not require a meet-up for a preselection process and the date give would be solely the  final for the selection process.

But .... why not meeting, discuss the inputs and probably generate a "fake christmas" close to summer to get quickly  more candidate pictures or inputs for an photomontage.


Your opinions please! I can try to organise tomorrow a small (very) tree and maybe some decoration (check, if you have something which would scale on a 35cm tree).

The weather is going to be nice tomorrow and we will have an "blue hour" at around 22:30.
Playing with the "depth of field", some motion blur maybe flashes and other ideas it may be possible to create something?
We could meet at a "scenic" spot in Brussels, probably somewhere, where I can bring the truck to have 240V power for some light ....

Possible locations:
- Sainte Catherine
- Sablon
- Cathedrale Saints Michel
Parc du Cinquantenaire

Preferable Sainte Catherine

Your opinion is required! Please use the discussion!

-----------------------------------------------------


Update 27 June SUBMISSION IS OPEN NOW !!!


Photo Submission

Photoresk's prestigious support the charity initiative of the Lions Club Bruessel Charlemagne for the benefit of severely ill children starts the next level:

Submission of Photos starts now and is open until the 6th of July.

Have your pictures and your name on the Lions Advent Calendar!!!

Please read the instructions below, check your archive and click <a>here</a> to submit your picture (8 mega pixel minimum)!

(if the link does not work - please e-mail your picture to [masked] and mention LionsCalender2014 in the subject)


After manual approval, you will receive a reference link to the submitted photos.

Rules

Image submission must be entrant’s original creation and must be owned 100% by the entrant.

Each entrant may deliver one or more images for this contest.


The image must have an resolution of at least 8 mega pixels.

Entries may originate in any format — including, but not limited to digital files, digital prints, color transparencies, color prints, or black and white prints — so long as they are submitted electronically.
Watermarked submissions are not acceptable.

The organiser reserves the right to remove image submissions deemed inappropriate solely at the discretion of the organiser.
The organiser reserves the right to republish any photos submitted for the purpose of this initiative.

------------------ more Details are below --------

What

Photoresk received the invitation to support the charity initiative of the German speaking Lions Club Bruessel Charlemagne for the benefit of severely ill children. We are very proud of this ;-)


The Plan
Photoresk will donate the best suitable and available christmas picture or collage to the Lions Club Bruessel Charlemagne to make their advent calendar really special (what is an advent calendar?)

example: the advent calendar picture 2013

More detail
Since many years the Lions Club Bruessel Charlemagne makes a wonderful contribution to important charity programs. Key of this initiative is the advent calendar. By selling this advent calendar, other donations and a tombola support is given to the charity "La Cité Sérine" (further details about "La Cité Serine" at: <a>www.serine-asbl.org)</a>

What to do
You are kindly invited to check your archive or be creative at your desk.
It must be  Winter / Christmas relates scene from Brussels. This can be a photograph or an collage suitable for DIN-A3 print.

It's the nature of an advent calendar that 24 small doors will be opened throughout the days - the visual impression should not be completely distracted by that.

The selection
We will have an fair and secured pre-selection process followed by an selection meetup where we will chose the five best.

Please, not the Grande Place
Since the Grand Place was already many times subject of this picture, for 2014 it should be preferably another location

Prestigious project
Helping Lions to help children should be by itself reward enough. But this is not all. Your name will be published along with your picture on the front of the advent calendar for free!

What to do now
Sign up for this meetup (you also may invite your friends). Check your archive. Have your best images  for this great initiative ready. You will receive more instructions later.

About Lions
LIONS is a worldwide service organisation comprising approximately 1.3 million members. Members of LIONS commit themselves to their maxim “We serve“ for all needy fellow men and women. LIONS aim to foster tolerance within human society. They especially want to promote general welfare, developing friendly relations among nations and thereby strengthening peace in the world. LIONS assist fellow men and women who suffer from material, physical and mental distress. LIONS also try to preserve our cultural heritage.

Your rights


Your photographs help children in need. Thank you for helping to further the mission of the Lionsclub Charlemagne mission through your photography.

You will retain all rights to any photograph you submit including ownership if applicable.

You only grant the Lionsclub Charlemagne rights (as described below) to your photograph if your photo is selected for the Lionsclub Charlemagne calendar 2014.

If your photo is selected for the Lionsclub Charlemagne calendar 2014 you grant the Lionsclub Charlemagne a royalty-free, nonexclusive right, in perpetuity, to:

Use the photograph to publish it on their Charity Calendar 2014 and supporting activities, including news stories, newsletters, reports, slide shows, displays, web pages, and the like.

Questions?
Feel free to use the discussion or to contact the organiser.

description:
Update 9/9/2014
 Hi All,
Yesterday I've checked out the location and the moon at Cinquantenaire.

Honestly, I did not expect the Supermoon to look like a big cheesecake in the sky but it could have been a bit bigger. Maybe I was suffering from the moon-illusion [wikipedia]  I've learnt something new... ;-)

You will definitely need a long lens or zoom in a lot.
I've noticed too:
It was an interesting idea to see the moon through the Arcs but probably doesn't look nice on photos.
* There is still the flag in the center arc moving in the wind spoiling all HDR attempts.
* The "back-side" of the Monument is not well illuminated and it will be completely dark by 21:15.  


The view from Cinquantenaire towards Montgomery might be more promising.

It will be better if we meet on the place between the two museums, towards Montgomery. We will be such a large group, not to miss ;-)

---------------------------------------------------

Update 8/9/2014:

Dear all -

in a comment earlier, I've pointed to an internet site which explains nicely some techniques to photograph the moon / super moon.
http://www.cnet.com/how-to/how-to-take-photos-of-the-supermoon/


with two remarks: No remote shutter release? use the self-timer of the camera, this helps to avoid shake when pressing the shutter No tripod? put your camera on something solid. A small sand-bag (freezer bag, loosely filled with rice, sugar or similar) helps to set the camera

Pointing to web-sites is not the new style of our learning and sharing network, however, when I proposed this meetup, I expected around 10 to 20 Happy Shuttercounts to sign up. Now we are close to hundert... But don't forget: It's about learning from each other - ask and share your knowledge.

Hope the weather is with us ;-)
Check back to this site, more updates to follow.

  ---------------------------- end of update ----------

Supermoon From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia


A supermoon is the coincidence of a full moon or a new moon with the closest approach the Moon makes to the Earth on its elliptical orbit, resulting in the largest apparent size of the lunar disk as seen from Earth. The technical name is the perigee-syzygy of the Earth-Moon-Sun system. The term "supermoon" is not astronomical, but originated in modern astrology.[1] The association of the Moon with both oceanic and crustal tides has led to claims that the supermoon phenomenon may be associated with increased risk of events such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, but the evidence of such a link is widely held to be unconvincing.[2]

The most recent occurrence was on August 10, 2014. The next and closest supermoon of 2014 will be on September 9.[3]

The supermoon at 9. September will align with the axis Cinquantenaire - Montgomery at around 21:46 at an elevation of 13,9°
A nice opportunity to picture the full moon which seems to be 13% larger as usual. Bring your tripod or borrow one  (use the discussion). 

We will have some photographic related discussions and a snack / drink before or after. Details will follow.
name: Supermoon at Cinquantenaire (only if we have clear sky)

description:
Another update:

Come at 20:45 to Slegerslaan corner Louis Gribaumontlaan and/or  22:15 to Cinquantenaire, the place between the museums and the fountain if we have clear sky


Rue de la Loi is cancelled.

--------------------------------------------------------------


Update 10/9: despite the uncertainties of today's cloud coverage - 
after yesterdays experience, I've re-checked the calculations.

The moon will align with the axis Rue de la Loi quite late - at 22:58 and already high in the sky at an elevation of 20°. Not really optimal for pictures along the street canyon (which in any case would change from Rue de la Loi to Rue Belliard to 'follow' the lights of the traffic).

I suppose 22:58 is too late?

Shall we cancel this meetup or change the location?

There are surprisingly not many streets in Brussels in the right angle for a good view on the rising moon (ca. 80° azimuth).

One option would be at Slegerslaan / Louis Gribaumontlaan: https://www.google.be/maps/dir/A.J.+Slegerslaan,+1200+Sint-Lambrechts-Woluwe/50.840453,4.4174099/@50.8424671,4.4200934,17z/data=!4m8!4m7!1m5!1m1!1s0x47c3db599b6b0307:0x253bfacbed30c1e4!2m2!1d4.4233269!2d50.8407782!1m0

At the roundabout Slegerslaan / Louis Gribaumontlaan is only a very small time-window from 20:55 to 21:05 to spot the rising moon at a low angle of 2,1° (can't guarantee for that) which makes it really look big.... but it may not be worth to go there outside this times.


Please communicate your view in the discussion, depending on the reaction the meetup will be re-located or cancelled.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Update: exact location will be anounced after the "Supermoon at Cinquantenaire meetup"

----------------------------------

We will picture the big supermoon Brusselshenge'ish along the axis Rue de la Loi

details and exact time after some calculations ;-)


Brusselshenge'ish from Manhattanhenge http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattanhenge

description:
Update:  (HDR and Shoes)

• from 19:30 on, Daniel will tell us how he created his wonderful HDR pictures of abandoned places.

• The ShoeFie machine will be in action. Taking automatically FREE pictures from different angles of your right shoe - they will go on Fotki and FB 

• After closing the venue, we may go for a drink to the Moeder Lambic, it's just around the corner


---- end of update --- 

The first time.


Six Happy Shuttercounts have organised this interesting exhibition for you.


A première - the first time such an event is happening under the umbrella of Photoresk.

From the mini-site:
"Six independent Photographers come together in this unique private exhibition. Discover their work. Explore their different views. Follow them on a journey into diversity. Different portfolios, different views and different perspectives ranging from experimental and abstractionism to nature and documentary. Strongly connected and tied by their devotion and shared passion for photography. All photographers are members of Photoresk, the global, inter-cultural photography knowledge sharing and learning network. "

It takes place at DoRéMi, Rue des Vierges 14-20, a few minutes from La Bourse and Place St. Gery.

We meet at the venue from 18:30 on (yes, you can come later ;-) , see and discuss and on go for a drink later.

Details about the expo on our mini-site:

http://disclosure.photoresk.com/
name: Dis/closure - Photoresk Exhibition #1

description:
Beautiful and mystical
It's a place close to Brussels, easily accessible for everybody.
If the weather is nice, it's beautiful, if not, it can be even mystical. Especially when autumn spreads it's decent colours everywhere. Surprisingly it's not very well known among the expat scene. It is the National Botanic Garden of Belgium in Meise (a bit - ca. 3km - north of the Atomium).
Outside, there are so many different types of trees which you will rarely see arranged like this anywhere in the world! Not enough, the large greenhouse with its amazing variety of plants is also worth a visit.
http://www.br.fgov.be/index.php


last year in October

What to bring
So, bring of course your camera, if you have, your macro and zoom equipment and whatever you may need for landscape AND close-ups. Of course, we will as usual discuss, ask and explain as we go. Don't worry, if you don't have a special photo gear. I have seen stunning pictures which were taken with an instamatic.

What we will do
Also this time, we will be a good mix of experts and beginners sharing the same passion and don't forget: there is always someone who knows something which all the others don't know. We also will have a small challenge for the excitement ;)

What if
As usual, we can expect the weather condition will be perfect for that day, we will meet in any case and in case its raining heavily, there is also the greenhouse and there are some shelters in the park.

Autmnpicknick
Bring some cheese/sausage/etc. and something to drink. We will try to have a pick-nick, probably in on of those tiny weather shelters.   

How to get  there
<a>http://www.br.fgov.be/PUBLIC/GENERAL/howtoreach.php
</a> Adress: Jardin botanique national de Belgique
Nieuwelaan 38
1860 Meise
By Car. We also can do some car-sharing. Start the discussion.
By Bus to Meise. Stop is "Nationale Plantentuin".
You can use the planner: http://www.delijn.be/en/index.htm with the street address above. In practical terms, we may form two groups. One is coming by bus from Brussels, the others go directly.

Questions
If you have any questions, please contact the organizer or start a discussion.

Links
General http://www.br.fgov.be/PUBLIC/GENERAL/index.php
name: Autumn colors and/or tropical heat

All of you have already received the invitation to
Dis/closure Photoresk Exhibition #1
and many of you already visited this first public exhibition of our group.

Saturday will be the final day, we open in the regularly during the afternoon and for the Finnisage (from 19:00 to 23:00), entrance is free.


For the last time in this combination to see:

• the prints from the 'Happy Shuttercounts' Alexanda, Claus, Daniel, Eva, Kevin and Luc,


• projections of random pictures from the past 76 (!) Photoresk Brussels meetups, 

• we also will have a modern dance session and


• food available at modest prices (with all the profit going directly to help the charity).

But we still need are photographer(s) for the event and seek volunteer(s) to take pictures at the Finnissage!

more info about our Photoresk event and the location here:
http://disclosure.photoresk.com

Of course, you are free to bring your camera and take pictures if you come 'only' as visitor but it would also be great if we would have one or two 'Happy Shuttercounts' who 'commit' as "Event Photographer" for the whole or parts of the evening. Your pictures will find a prominent place at our web-site and on Facebook.

Thank you!!!

;-) 

PS The official "Event Photographer(s)" will be on the first-come, first-serve basis :-) - probably two at a time (19:00 - 20:00,
20:00 -21:00,
21:00 - 22:00,
22:00 - 23:00)
would be sufficient.
Use the discussion for co-ordination.
name: Photoresk - seeking support "Event Photographer" in own matters

description:
The Museum of Photography in Charleroi is situated in Mont-sur-Marchienne in a former convent. It is the largest and one of the most important museums of photography in Europe, spread over a 6000m² space, with a collection of 80,000 photographs, of which 800 are permanently exhibited.

We'll get a guided tour during 1,5 hours , in English of course  ;-)

After that we will have a walk along the industrial landscapes of Charleroi, according to some people the ugliest city in the world, but ideal for photography enthusiasts!

Don't miss this opportunity...


The small letters
The guide had to be booked in advance so a pre payment of 5 EUR (this includes entry to the permanent collection of the museum and the guide) to the Organizer's account will be asked after you subscribed via Meetup.
Due to the guided tour, places are limited to max. 20 people.
Please be on time as guides can be scrupulous ;-)


What to bring
Obviously, your camera or anything that has a camera... The rest is up to you: a lens for landscapes, a CPL,...
Walking shoes, a small backpack with some refreshments during our walk and an umbrella or something that protects your gear and yourself in case of rain.


What we will do
- 10:30 sharp – 12:00 : Guided tour in museum.
- Lunch (a sandwich, salad or pasta dish from the Museum Café OR bring your own food).
- Afternoon: walk along industrial buildings and graffiti walls. I can't give an exact timing of start and end but the walk is roughly 15 km long.


What if it rains?
Fortunately the museum has a roof  ;-)
In case of rain there is always an option to stay longer in the museum and start our walk in Charleroi later.
In case of very very heavy rain... then we decide what to do on that moment.


How to get there
Museum of Photography
Avenue Paul Pastur 11
6032 Charleroi

By Car:
Offers or Requests for car sharing can be published on the conversation board below.

By Public transport:
Charleroi-Sud train station,
then take bus 70 or 71 or 170 (get out at 'Mont-sur-Marchienne place').
More details here.

Questions
If you have any questions, please contact the organizer or start a discussion.
name: Two sides of Charleroi: Museum of Photography and Industrial landscapes

description:
Photo Booth on Friday Night


Shooting at Vintage „Dance and More“ Event

Photoresk Brussels was asked if we were interested to volunteer at events of Swing It Brussels, hosting the Lindy Hop exchange .
What a great opportunity for beautiful,  vintage shots!!!


What
Swing it Brussels asbl is looking for  photographer(s) for a series of events 14 - 16 November, the BRUX Lindy Exchange.
It is a packed weekend. Parties on Friday, Saturday and Sunday (even on Monday 17th November) and day activities on Saturday and Sunday afternoon.


Details
You can find details about the event(s) here:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/swingitbrussels/?fref=ts
http://www.brux2014.com/program


You need to know before RSVP
The number of participants is very limited this event. You should have some experience in event shooting. When you RSVP „yes“ for the event, you should commit to participate and - if you, for any reason, have to change your plans, modify your RSVP accordingly to free you place for someone else ASAP.


If more are interested in this event than places available, preference may be give to those with a clean no-show record from previous meetups.


There will be no Photoresk organiser as usual. After you are confirmed, you will receive the contact details of the organiser at Swing It Brussels event for further information and co-ordination.

This is a no-money involved Photoresk meetup as usual ;-)  

That is the agreement with Swing It Brussels

1. the photographer can use the pictures for her/his portfolio etc.
2. agrees to make the photos available on your web- and facebook pages (see below)
3. gets free entrance to the events
4. the participants to the events agree that pictures will be taken and published
5. when publishing the images, the photographer will be credited by mentioning his/her name
6. The pictures will be published on the Photomask Brussels Meetup site, the Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/events/1429961567278516/?ref_dashboard_filter=upcoming) and on the website (http://www.brux2014.com/).
7. the images will be made available for download
name: Photo Booth on Friday Night - Vintage / Lindy Hop
